question: Question_06_(b)
statement:
Use the formuala $|\text{Error}| \leq \frac{M}{2}(x-a)^2,$ where
$M > 0$, to estimate an error bound for your approximation of
$\sqrt[3]{7}$ from
\href{Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH104/December 2013/Question 06 (a)}{part
(a)}. It will be useful to remember how to find such an $M.$
sols:
Our function we are considering is $\displaystyle f(x) = x^{1/3}$.
Taking derivatives gives

$\displaystyle f'(x) = x^{-2/3}/3$

$\displaystyle f''(x) = -2x^{-5/3}/9$

On the interval of length 1 around the point 8, we see that the maximum
value on the second derivative of the absolute value of the double
derivative is given by

$\displaystyle |f''(x)| = |-2x^{-5/3}/9| \leq 2x^{-5/3}/9 \leq 2\cdot7^{-5/3}/9$

true since the function $\displaystyle x^{-5/3}$ is a decreasing
function. Thus, the absolute value of hte error is bounded by

$\displaystyle 2\cdot7^{-5/3}/18 \cdot (9-8)^{2} = 2\cdot7^{-5/3}/18$
hints:
To find a value for M, it would suffice to find an upper bound on the
second derivative and use this as the value for \emph{M}.
